text:
PROFESSOR: All right, I'd like
to talk about this next project
in about four different ways.

And I'm going to break it down
and you might take some notes,
if you would.

The first will be
about the site.
The second is about the program.

The third is what we're doing
in terms of the architecture,
the space, the determinants.

And the fourth is
this issue of nature,

if we call it that,
quote, in the city.

So I'm going to
start with the site.
Jen has for you--

and she'll be here--
a copy of the section

at 16th scale to site,
this photo montage

of the site, a 16th scale
plan, and an eighth scale plan.

She should have,
when she arrives,
copies of everything of this.
The site is no stranger to you.

You do know it, some
of you intimately.

Sorry, well, here and
certainly these two guys,

and many of them, as you
know, looking into it.

The site is roughly an
area that is like this
and is an interesting site.

I won't call it difficult,
but it's an interesting site.

And there are some
ways of describing it.

For the purpose of
this project, we

are considering it to
be completely flat.

It's not entirely flat, but it's
close enough for being flat.

There is a driveway that
goes down to a garage

here that we're
considering isn't there

that shouldn't have been there
in the first place, actually.
It's illegal.

But we're considering
it's not there.

There is a-- and you can see
on here-- called a lane--

Lands Court, which I probably
would guess originally there

was houses like this here, and
then houses like this here,

and the tunnel came along
and blasted everything away

because they probably had
to dig underneath this

to do this because
this is where, I think,
the tunnel goes down.
So that's why it's like this.

But for the purpose
of our project,
this is part of our site.

And this is also
part of our site.

Therefore, we don't worry about
cars going back through here.
They don't do it now.
This is parking.
This is nothing.
And this is a playground.

And we're just going to
forget about the playground
for the time being.

I know, Felix, you
may not like that,

but you can move
it over to here,

which is a nice
playground space,
or incorporate it into your--
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: So that's the first
point, is that it's flat.

And the right of ways and
the driveways you can keep--
I mean, you ignore.

There are, however, some
nice trees that you have
to think about, I think two.

But oh, they don't
look very nice on this.

Oh no, here they are
there, yeah, two.
There's one here I didn't know.

Oh, this little building you
don't worry about either.
It's not on here.

There's a little building
here, but forget that.

Whenever in architecture
you destroy a tree,
think about it very seriously.

You can now transplant
trees, but they're expensive.

These are not mature
trees by any means,

but they have had a life
of 20, probably 25 years.

That doesn't mean you can't
take them or relocate them.

But think about
it before you do.

I have the following
criteria for you

that this wall, which
has windows on it,
you have to keep those windows.

And therefore,
somehow you've got
to get light into these guys.

However, this one,
which has windows on it,

you don't have to keep because
in the North End vocabulary
it's on the corner.

But most of the time,
it does not have windows
because it's a bearing wall.

This one may not have
been because of the lane.

But we can assume that
there's no windows here.

You are welcome to build
then up against this--

whoops, up against
this, but not--
not against this.

And of course, you're
welcome to build up

against the ventilator building
in any way you see fit,
as we've already done.
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: This class is
a good poke-through class.

There's been a lot of poking
that's been going on here.
Three or four have been poking.

Yes, you can poke,
which I don't think
you can poke in this territory.
AUDIENCE: Just like the big--

AUDIENCE: Are we
taking the [INAUDIBLE]??

I'm assuming that
all these are there.

PROFESSOR: Well, in theory,
yes, this is your community.
You're all living here now.
And that relates to the program.

And you should be
thinking about that.

But you may have a
discussion with her
if you feel it's important.

And there's one
here that you need
to have a discussion with you.

AUDIENCE: Can just have
a little elevator shaft
come right up to my house?

PROFESSOR: Well,
in all these cases,

you're getting into your house
in some way, which we're not

worrying about, but it's not
on the site except for her.

So she may have to
modify it slightly.
So got it so far?
With me?

Again, just to put it in
perspective, this is at 16th.
This is at eighth.

We're going to start
working at 16th.

And then we'll move to eighth,
and quarter, and full size,
and so on.
Well, we may.

I'm hoping that
we're going to build

a piece of this [INAUDIBLE],,
not the whole thing.

Now, there's another issue
that I want to talk about,

which is what I call the
ordinary and the extraordinary.

And that is that there's an
ordinary environment coming
down this street--

boom, boom, boom--
and then there's

something that you might call
extraordinary, but not very
nice, the ventilator tower.

And in the nature
of this design,

I'd like to have to pay
attention to the ordinary

as it relates to this, if
you so choose to work here,

which does not
mean fake colonial

or whatever this
is by any means,

but it means being
compatible to it.

And then you might move
into something that's
more unusual, extraordinary.

So we're going from the
ordinary on this side
to the extraordinary.
That makes sense?

The site has one more
interesting and difficult
issue.
What is it?
AUDIENCE: Sector off the grid.

PROFESSOR: Yes, it
does have that, too,

and that's an interesting
issue, but there's another one.
AUDIENCE: Is it on a grade?
PROFESSOR: Sorry?
AUDIENCE: Is it on a grade?
PROFESSOR: No, it's flat.
We're making it flat.
AUDIENCE: Dead space?
PROFESSOR: Huh?
AUDIENCE: Dead space?

PROFESSOR: Well, it's
a bunch of dead spaces.

And that's our point of
taking it to make life to it.
What else about the site?
AUDIENCE: The street [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: Forget about
this and forget about this.
AUDIENCE: The height of it?

PROFESSOR: What
about the height?

AUDIENCE: Well, it's
[INAUDIBLE] That's

like the water part of it or
the lower part [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: Yeah, but, and?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]
PROFESSOR: Huh?
Come on, come on.

AUDIENCE: The thing's
blocking the sun in there.

So you don't have
a lot of light.

PROFESSOR: Yeah,
it's not a nice site.
I mean, you've got a--
the sun is in the--
let's do it.

The sun in the winter is
rising somewhere here .

I think it might
get a little light.

No, not at rise, but
maybe at noon it's
going to get some light.

And then it's coming around and
setting probably about here.

It might get a
little light on here.
On the summer, it's better.

It's rising over here and
probably gets some light,

and maybe get some
light all day.

But clearly, these guys, being
so tall, are casting shadows.

Most sites that you get
in architectural school

are south-facing with
a beautiful view.
That's not the case here.

This is north-facing
with a great view

because we're seeing
Sarah's wonderful building
across the street.
But it's different.

So light is an extremely
important issue--

how we bounce light around, how
we get sunlight down into it.
And that makes this site unique.
You have to think about that.

I want you to go back to the
site and look at the site

now from the eyes of
this project, which
I'm going to give you.

And of course,
you're aware of it.

One of the things
that did not come out

in the last project, which
you might think about,

is views from this site
that you might see--

Custom House Tower down
the street, et cetera.

Next question-- what are
we going to do with it?

This is the most
important part, I think.

We are going to make
and design a place here

that will bring
together you guys

and your community in the
sky, North Enders, who

are living here,
tourists, and anyone else

you might think of into
a meeting place, which

used to be called a community
center which of course, is

the kiss of death to
making anything community.

If you ever label it a community
center, nobody will go there.

So we're not making, in the
typical sense, a community

center, but we are
making a place for people
to come together.

In our age, in
this age, you guys

could sit here all day long on
your computer and do something.

But there may be a question
about the quality of life

that you have that may want you
to get out for some reason--
for work or for whatever.

We are making that place
of bringing together

not only you guys, but also
North Enders because life

is about meeting other
people and architecture

is about bringing
people together.

So we're making a
coming-together space.
That's our program, basically.
And that's up to you to decide.

To be a good architect
is important,
to be a good designer.

But to be a good
programmer, to think

about the spirit of what the
architecture is going to be
is a real genius.

And that's what I'm
asking you guys to be.

I'm asking you to be very
creative in thinking about what

brings people together, and then
design the most beautiful place
for it.

I believe very much in this way
of working because otherwise I

think you come out to be
technocrats in the way

that you are just
hired architects
and do what somebody tells you.

And I believe that the
architectural profession
can offer more than that.
You're not engineers.

You're not designing
just a bridge to stay up.

You're designing life
or an echo of life.

So in this case, what
is it that the echo is?

The program, which I'll
hand out in a second,

is about 6,000
square feet of stuff,

which is more than-- that's
about-- well, you all cheated,

but that's about six of
these, five of these.
Or it should be.

So somehow, you're
going to get 6,000--
roughly 6,000, it can be more.

There should be, in that
program, no matter what you're

doing, some space in there
where a good number of people

can meet together,
a meeting place.
I don't know what that is.

Is that an exhibition
hall for art?
Is that a movie theater?
Is that an ice skating rink?
I don't know what it is.
That's up to you to think about.

There should be
some spaces in here

that are medium size where
people might come together

to have meetings, or
day care, or elder care.

And there should be some
small spaces in here
where you might work.

Maybe you work all day on your
computer in a virtual world,

but your true life
is making furniture.

And we may be shifting in our
ways of thinking about work
and life as it's been before.

So maybe you make
furniture there

and you sell it on your
computer in your house.
I don't know.
That's up to you.
So it might be workspaces there.

The point is there's some
small, there's some medium size,
and there's one big one.

As I said before,
all good architecture

has a vertical connection and a
horizontal connection of space.

This building should have that,
a vertical and a horizontal.

So therefore,
space, in some way,

should be flowing through
the building vertically
and horizontally.

Some part of the
building, but not all,

should get up to be a companion
to these other buildings, which
is three stories or so.

But the whole thing
doesn't have to do that.

Now, let me just put in
parentheses part of this

project is to get you to
think about three-dimensional

programming and how you
express that architecturally

because, for the most part,
you've been doing it on--

in your head, you're able to
keep track of one, or two,
or three stories.
But now, you can't.

You're going to have to think
three-dimensionally and work
three-dimensionally.

So the program is intended
not to be a horizontal suburb
community center, right?
It's not that.

About two thirds of the
side should be left open

or left untouched so that, which
isn't the last part of this--

that wonderful
experience that we

had the very first day of
going to the Quarry of nature--

call it nature, water-- it
wasn't nature, but that's OK.

We, in some form, are
bringing nature back

into the city, which
is badly needed
in this part of the city.

Nothing is staying
this here, but I'm

inviting you to think
about what does it

mean to bring nature back into
the city for a place that's

as dense as this that they have
one tree here, and one here,

and, I guess, some
here, no water anywhere

except for the fountain
in the Paul Revere's Walk.

To my knowledge, no natural
stone or no natural--

so-called natural grass in
anywhere in the North End

for a community,
maybe privately.
So what does that mean?

You might bring
water into this site

because it used to
be water, by the way.
This was a shoreline.

You might bring
trees into this site.

But if you're bearing trees,
do not do what architects do,

which is what I call throwing
darts at the drawing 10 minutes

before it's due
and placing trees.

And then you put trees, and then
you put little benches on it

and you call it
open space and you

think people are going to
live happily ever after,
and they're not.

It's going to have to be more
than that if you do trees
or any kind of vegetation.

It could be a way
of using materials--
stone from the Quarry--

I mean, maybe you go
back to the Quarry

and get some Quarry materials
and bring it here and civilize

it in some way, combine
it with water and trees.

That's up to you to
decide what that is.

But when you're done
with this and this,

people no longer are
going down the red line
to see Paul Revere's house.

They're going down a purple
line to see your place

because it's much
better than anything
that they've ever seen.

So those people are coming
from Ohio, where I came from,

could care less
about Paul's place,

but they really care
about your place,

such as the little park
in New York where there's
a waterfall at the back.
I never know the name of it.
You know that one?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: Yeah,
wonderful little oasis

in the middle of
chaos, in my opinion.
Those are special places.

That's what you're making,
a very special place.

So that's the turn or
the complete James Joyce

cycle from the
beginning of the Quarry

back to something
like the Quarry.
You with me, guys?

Well I've already said that the
ordinary and the extraordinary

has to be combined
somehow on this site.

So you're not parking a
spaceship in here now.

[HUMMING] That's not
what you're doing.

It's not a landing
field, landing pad.

Sorry, you thought
I'd forgotten,

but I will remember
it for 20 years.

So you're not doing
that, but you're also
not imitating what's there.
It's a bore.
Don't do that.

No, you guys-- none of
you guys did that in this.

How can you make a
billboard in there

like that, which
I'm not suggesting
you did, but also relate?

Incredible problem, beautiful
idea, how to do that?
I don't know.

But that's what you're--
that's your challenge.

Finally, in my opinion,
in any good building,

it's the public space of
paths and places, which I will
talk about the space between.

The assignment, number 6
in the sequence of things,

first [INAUDIBLE] which
is due next Tuesday,
I'm going to read it.

For this assignment,
you are asked

to think about what this
building wants to be.
I'm asking you again.

What is the program that
would satisfy your needs

and bring people together
in the community?

How can we get people
to come together?
Again, I'm reiterating.

What kind of spaces for work
would you want and need?

How can we design buildings
in our present society--

present society
being the society
of technology of computers--

that can bring people
together and address
the issue of community?

Because we still-- we still
want to come together somehow.

Yet, the machine and
the technology age

is pushing us away from each
other to a certain extent.

What is the
connection to nature,
which is also basic need of us?

How can nature be
introduced into the city?

These are all questions I'm
asking you for the program.

I say it would be a good
time to revisit the site

and understand more
of the community.

You might do this by being there
at different times of the day,

by talking with people
who lived there,

or by understanding the
history of the area, which

you do understand to a
certain extent, but more so.

So you might go down
today, go in the night,
go on the weekend with somebody.

From your observations, ideas
for the program and form
should come.
Got it?

For next Tuesday, we're
going to have a pin-up.
The following should be done--

two 20-by-50 boards to
include your attitude, quote,

"attitude," about the building,
program uses, and sizes.

I'm looking for you to
produce montage boards again

that express your idea about
how we're going to come together
on this site.

I'm also asking you to
make areas of colored paper

to show the sizes of the program
at the scale 16th which we're
working at, which is this.

That talks about the
size of the building.

Remember, this is a
vertical building.

AUDIENCE: So that's
on the boards.
PROFESSOR: That's on the boards.

And I'm asking you
sketches about how
you might use the site.

Include at 1/16 scale at
least one general sketch plan,
but more--
I'm looking for more than one.
